results.title: How to conduct a discussion
results.brief_description: Designed to assist in the promotion, organisation and conduct of discussion groups as a method of adult education. Illustrates various methods of discussion group organisation and the necessary qualities of a good leader.

results.title: How to concentrate
results.brief_description: Demonstrates techniques which facilitate concentration - looking for answers to questions, selecting one idea at a time, avoiding distractions, and employing periodic relaxation. For junior and senior high school, college and adult groups.

results.title: How to catch a cold
results.brief_description: This film shows how colds are spread, how a day or so in bed protects the whole community, and how a cold may be the first symptoms of more serious illness.

results.title: How to build an igloo
results.creator_credit: Douglas Wilkinson, Michael Spencer and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A demonstration of igloo-building in Canada’s far North, showing how the site is selected and how blocks of snow are used to make a snug shelter against the Arctic cold. Two Eskimos staying overnight at a trading post construct an igloo in only an hour and a half. As the camera follows each stage in the process, the commentary explains why the snow must be so carefully chosen, why the blocks are built up in a spiral, and how the completed igloo is ventilated. Editing, Neil Harris. Script, Doug Wilkinson. Cinematography, Chester C. Kissick.

results.title: How to Be Your Dog's Best Friend
results.creator_credit: Bernard Thompson, Royal Society for the Prvention of Cruelty to Animals (Australia) and Video Media Production
results.brief_description: Dog ownership can be a great joy. However, it is also a great responsibility. This video presents a wide variety of expert information presented in a simple format designed to help you become your dog’s best friend and to help you increase the joy of dog ownership; choosing your dog, bringing your dog home, toilet training, health and happiness, veterinary advice, dog behaviour. Rated: G

results.title: How to be a professional mum or dad
results.brief_description: Examines strategies of Glenn Doman at the institute for the realization of Human Potential in America on development of learning in children in the first six years of life. Shows parents and children following his theories on the unlimited potential of children for absorbing knowledge.

results.title: How to avoid decisions
results.creator_credit: Ted Robinson, Eve Ash, Australian Film Commission, Seven Dimensions and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A humorous training video written by Ian McFadyen in the pre-Cleese era which aims to develop decision-making skills by examining common ways of avoiding decisions. A character called Art Dodger defends his title as World Decision-Avoiding champion and must prevent his staff from forcing him to face up to his decision making responsibilities. Provides a step-by-step process for effective decision-making. Cast includes Graeme Blundell.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ted Robinson, Eve Ash, Australian Film Commission, Seven Dimensions and Victorian Film Corporation

results.title: How to animate a gingerbread boy
results.brief_description: Demonstrates and explains the technique of motion picture animation. Intended for classroom use, this film illustrates various animation methods ranging from very simple to advanced and presents them in a way that explains the technical mysteries and permits the student to focus on the art of animation. The methods include cut-out, three-dimensional and time-lapse. A version of the gingerbread boy is told through the use of the various animation techniques discussed. (Ages 7-11 years.)

results.title: How things dissolve
results.brief_description: Deals with the physical changes which take place in the formation of various kinds of solution: solid in a liquid, gas in a gas and liquid in a liquid. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: How the whale got his throat
results.creator_credit: Stephen Bosustow and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: Rudyard Kipling’s whimsical story of how the whale got his sieve-like throat is the subject of this animated film. Long ago, after the whale has eaten all the fish in the sea, he decides to consume a sailor on a raft. Once inside the whale the man jumps about, causing hiccups, until the whale agrees to take him home to get rid of him. As he leaves the whale’s mouth at the trip’s end, the sailor lodges a huge grid, made from his cut-up raft, in the whale’s throat so that until this day the whale can eat only very small fish.
